importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The article is published just ahead of Diwali and Dhanteras, two key Hindu festivals when gold demand typically surges, making this date critical for understanding current market dynamics.

September marked record inflows into gold ETFs, indicating a significant shift in investor behavior toward digital and investment forms of gold, which is relevant to understanding the changing nature of gold demand in India.
The article notes that gold's share in India's foreign exchange reserves increased from 9% to 14% between 2024 and 2025, showing a long-term institutional shift in national monetary policy.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The festive and wedding season is expected to continue driving retail demand for gold and silver, despite high prices, placing this timeframe at the center of current market activity and consumer behavior.

keyTakeAways: Gold prices have surged to $1,440 per 10g, up 60% from previous levels, creating FOMO among buyers and increasing demand despite budget constraints.
India's gold demand is shifting from jewellery to investment products (bars, coins, ETFs), with investment demand rising from 19% to 35% in the second quarter of 2025.
Younger consumers are increasingly preferring lighter, more affordable jewellery, reflecting changing lifestyles and financial realities.
The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has increased its gold reserves from 9% to 14% of foreign exchange reserves, signaling a strategic shift in national monetary policy to diversify holdings.
Despite high prices, demand for gold remains strong, especially among the affluent, though lower-income families are being priced out of the market.
Indian households hold $3.8 trillion in gold, equivalent to 88.8% of GDP, indicating a deep cultural and economic reliance on gold as a wealth store and financial buffer.

summaryOfNewsArticle: This article explores the dynamics of India’s gold market ahead of Diwali and Dhanteras, highlighting how soaring gold prices—now exceeding $1,440 per 10g—have led to a shift in consumer behavior. While demand for gold jewellery remains strong due to cultural traditions, buyers are now opting for lighter, more affordable pieces or switching to investment forms like gold bars, coins, and ETFs. Data from the World Gold Council shows that investment demand has risen sharply, from 19% to 35% in a single year, while jewellery's share fell from 80% to 64%. The Reserve Bank of India has also increased its gold reserves, contributing to global demand. Despite high prices, the cultural attachment to gold and its role as a wealth store ensures sustained demand, though lower-income families are increasingly priced out, with some delaying purchases until prices fall.
title: Dhanteras: Why India's Diwali gold rush is different this year
